newsitem.title: CHINA: Microsoft, China Legend in licence pact.
newsitem.headline: Microsoft, China Legend in licence pact.

text.p: Microsoft Corp and China's Legend Group signed on Tuesday a software licensing agreement that officials of the two companies said could be worth 100 million yuan ($12 million) to Microsoft over the next two years.
The agreement licenses Legend, China's leading personal computer manufacturer, to pre-install Microsoft's Chinese language Windows 95 software in Legend personal computers.
"This is the most significant agreement Microsoft has signed in the People's Republic of China," said Charles Stevens, Microsoft vice president, Far East.
Stevens and other Microsoft officials told reporters at the signing ceremony that licensing fees would be linked to Legend's sales though they declined to give further financial details.
Legend officials said the company sold 200,000 personal computers in China last year and has set a target of 400,000 this year.
Chinese government officials have estimated that 1.8 million personal computers were sold in China overall last year.

Legend Group controls the Hong Kong-listed Legend. Legend officials said the income from the personal computers sold under the agreement with Microsoft would be largely reflected in the results of the Beijing operations.
The Windows 95 software to be installed in the Legend computers employs the simplified Chinese characters used in mainland China.
The two companies described their agreement as part of a strategic partnership that pointed to further cooperation in design in future.
Executives of the two companies and Chinese government officials hailed the agreement as part of Beijing's efforts to protect intellectual property rights.
The United States withdrew threatened trade sanctions against China in June last year after winning commitments to stamp out copyright piracy.
Washington had been pressing for Beijing to take decisive action to comply with an accord on intellectual property rights signed in 1995.
Chinese officials attending the ceremony hailed the pact between Legend and Microsoft as a sign that Beijing intended to enforce intellectual property rights.
"This shows the Chinese government's resolve to protect intellectual property rights," said Yu Zhongyu, chief engineer at the Ministry of Electronics Industry.
